Award.AwardTitle: Light scattering studies of organic field-effect transistors

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of this research is to investigate charge transport properties in interface-controlled organic field-effect transistors (OFETs) using light scattering techniques, with a long term goal of applying OFETs in memory devices. The approach includes (1) layer-by-layer growth of polymer films using pulsed laser deposition to control the semiconductor-dielectric interface in OFETs; (2) probing the dielectric-semiconductor interface using Raman spectroscopy from biased OFET structures and correlating the changes in the vibrational spectra with theory to identify the structural changes upon charge transport; (3) charge modulation spectroscopy of OFETs; (4) surface-enhanced Raman scattering from metal nanoparticle doped dielectric and organic semiconductors for memory applications.

The proposed research takes a comprehensive approach to probe charge transport in OFETs by combining light scattering techniques with conventional current-voltage characteristics, yielding information on electron-phonon interactions and structural changes at the interface. Such a technique has a potential transformative character as it promises to become a standard probe for studying charge transport mechanisms in a host of other optoelectronic devices. This hypothesis will be further put to test in organic memory applications where surface-enhanced Raman scattering studies will be carried out to gain insight into the operation of memory devices.

The broader impact of the work is demonstrated by recruitment of undergraduate interns including underrepresented minorities from Lincoln University (a Historically Black College & University) to give them opportunities in cutting-edge research. The proposed work involves participation and training of graduate students which will contribute to the US workforce in the area of organic optoelectronics.

POR.DRECONTENT:
During the grant period we have fulfilled our commitment in exploiting light scattering techniques to answer key questions pertaining to the local structure of conjugated systems and to probe the nature of vibronic coupling as well as structural changes associated with transport in organic field-effect transistors (FETs). A major focus of our research has been on improving the performance of FETs by controlling the polymer-dielectric interface by modifying the dielectric layer and incorporating new growth techniques for the polymer layer. We have developed a modified pulsed-laser deposition technique, matrix-assisted pulsed laser evaporation (MAPLE), for growing layer-by-layer organic films.

We have further expanded our research in the areas of triplet excitations in conjugated systems and application of triplet-enhanced polymers in organic devices; impact of metal deposition on the dielectric layer of FETs using high-resolution transmission electron microscopy; application of new donor-acceptor–type conjugated systems in organic devices. This has resulted in active collaboration with several neighboring institutions in the State of Missouri along with two international collaborations at the Indian Institute of Science-Bangalore: a synthetic chemistry group and a theoretical quantum chemistry group.

In a nutshell, the significant achievements of our work funded by the NSF are:

  1. Explaining the role of triplet excitations in charge transport and light-emission mechanisms.
  2. MAPLE approach for polymer growth in FETs
  3. Fabrication of low operating voltage and environmentally stable organic FETs and improvement of solution processable polymer dielectrics.
  4. Inelastic light scattering studies of organic molecule/polymer based FETs: Raman imaging, surface-enhanced Raman scattering (SERS), and vibrational spectroscopy calculations.

During this grant period, we have maintained our commitment to educate and train students in the area of organic optoelectronics. In all, four PhD students, three undergraduate students and two high school students have been involved with the project. The research project has enhanced the quality of the University’s research and educational programs, particularly in physics and electrical engineering. A new electrical characterization facility involving a probe station with microscopic imaging capabilities has been added to the PI’s research laboratory. This facility is being now utilized in the undergraduate Advanced Laboratory class, which was initiated by the PI a few years ago. Furthermore, the addition of a green laser to an existing Raman microscope has expanded our capabilities for resonance Raman and surface-enhanced Raman spectroscopy.

The broader impact of the proposed research may be summarized as:

  1. We have developed SERS/Raman mapping as a visualization tool to study the impact of bias on organic FETs. See Figure 1.
  2.  Curriculum enhancement in Advanced Physics Lab: trained 15 undergraduate students in organic electronics over the course of three years.
